text: <@U0YP7KFGQ|gennady.laventman> has joined the channel
@IBM what is your preferred way to debug the fabric code?
what aspect
I want to walk through the code via breakpoints. I used IntelliJ with the Go plugin but i am facing some issues. Therefore i am asking how do you debug....
i have not used breakpoint debugging so far - tool situation for go is not so good
are you interested in something specific?
<@U0MM86C84>: I have not used it myself but I know some who have had some success with Eclipse
<@U0XR6J961>: nothing specific,  get familiar with the code base
okay
<@U0ULK2JPP>: thank u for the information!
<@U0MM86C84>: sure thing…. can’t promise but I can try and find some info if you like
<@U0ULK2JPP>: that would be nice. I appreciate it!
<@U0MM86C84>: I use delve (<https://github.com/derekparker/delve>), works well

attachments.title: derekparker/delve
attachments.text: delve - Delve is a debugger for the Go programming language.

text: I wrote up a wiki entry on it
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/wiki/Go-Development-Portal>

attachments.title: hyperledger/fabric
attachments.text: fabric - Fabric is a blockchain project in Incubation proposed to the community and documented at <https://goo.gl/RYQZ5N>. Information on what Incubation entails can be found in the Hyperledger Proj...

text: its like command-line gdb style debugger, but it actually works with go
<@U0KPFAZNF>: Are you using delve within an IDE or in combination with the command line? Yes that would be helpful. Thanks!
just command line for debugging
I do use IntelliJ for editing Go, but not for debugging
<@U0KPFAZNF>: I will try the same. Let's see if i can fix the issues regarding the debugging within IntelliJ...
<@U0MM86C84>: I am not an expert by any stretch, but my understanding is that most IDEs have not really integrated go debugging into their go support
so not sure how much success you will find there
<@U0KPFAZNF>: I tried it with a simple Go project and it works..
Delve or IntelliJ?
<@U11G06X52|shsedghi> has joined the channel
I use Eclipse with GO and OBC for sometime. I can do almost everything that I do in Java with GO except when I click on a variable it does not highlight all. Debugging , outline are as good as Java.
<@U0MM86C84> … <@U11G06X52> was the person I had in mind on Eclipse/GO
It woukd be interesting to compare <@U0KPFAZNF> Delve and Eclipse/GO
(thanks <@U11G06X52> )
<@U0KPFAZNF>: Debugging within IntelliJ
ah, cool, things must have really improved
when I first starting looking at go last summer, it was poorly supported in the IDEs I tried
debugging wise, i mean
<@U0KPFAZNF>: Eclipse GO plugin (GOClipse) relies on 2-3 other GO packages to do that, and it does an awesome job.
awesome, ill check it out (though I prefer IntelliJ, but I suspect they are in similar support levels)
I will put the setup procedure and Best practices with Eclipse GO when I learn how to update WIKI.
<@U11G06X52>: Would be nice

<@U0MM86C84>: <@U0KPFAZNF> <@U0ULK2JPP> 
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/wiki/Go-Development-Portal> update with Goclipse setup, pictures are available and will be update later

attachments.fallback: [April 17th, 2016 11:45 PM] ibmamnt: Appreciate if someone in this channel can answer my question. How to find chaincodeID deployed to the network ?   I'm aware "obc-peer chaincode deploy (with code location)" will return the chaincodeID.name value. However, I have not memoried it unfortunately. How can I find the chaincodeID.name value ?
attachments.text: Appreciate if someone in this channel can answer my question. How to find chaincodeID deployed to the network ?   I'm aware "obc-peer chaincode deploy (with code location)" will return the chaincodeID.name value. However, I have not memoried it unfortunately. How can I find the chaincodeID.name value ?

text: How do I obtain chaincodeID.name value after the deploy ?

<@U11CP8FF1>: there is no easy way to do that today. You can get transactions from a block, unmarshal with code etc. which clearly is not desirable. There is discussion of a naming service which when implemented will solve naming issues
<@U0ULK2JPP>: Thanks for the answer. In a debug mode, I can put arbitrary name via CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME env. So obtaining name is not high priority at this moment.
<@U11CP8FF1>: that’s good to know
